photos.title: The Road at Rezovo
photos.alt: This is the only road to Rezovo. As we have previously mentioned, it is very narrow so that the attacking Turkish forces can hardly advance in war times :)

sections.content: This photo shows **the only road to Rezovo**, which is described as **very narrow**. The humorous historical context suggests it's narrow enough to impede invading forces, highlighting the village's isolated, border location and limited accessibility.

This photo captures the **border** area at Rezovo, which is situated directly on the boundary between Bulgaria and Turkey. This signifies the village's unique geopolitical location at the southeastern edge of the EU.

This photo features a **crucifix** at Rezovo, indicating the village's deep-rooted Christian traditions and cultural heritage, especially given its location near a border with a predominantly Muslim country.

This photograph captures the **beach** area at Rezovo, showing the sand quality and coastal conditions. The beach is notable for its proximity to the Turkish border, offering a unique setting on the Bulgarian Black Sea coast.

photos.title: River at Rezovo
photos.alt: River Rezovo is the exact border line between Bulgaria and Turkey.

sections.content: This photo shows the **Rezovo River**, which is explicitly identified as the **exact border line between Bulgaria and Turkey**. This feature is central to the village's identity and geographical significance at the national and European boundary.
This photo captures the view toward the **Turkish border** from Rezovo, illustrating the geographical proximity to the neighboring country and providing context for the village's strategic position.

photos.title: Eu Border at Rezovo
photos.alt: This is to show the Turkish that the European Union's border is in front of them... It is a pity however, that Bulgaria is the last country in the EU to be proud of its membership...

sections.content: This photo shows a marker indicating the **European Union's border** is at this location, directly facing the Turkish side. The accompanying comment reflects a critical, local perspective on Bulgaria's standing within the EU despite holding a crucial external boundary.
This photograph provides a view of the **Turkish Beach** area from the Bulgarian side in Rezovo, allowing visitors to see the landscape and development of the neighboring coastline across the border.

This photograph captures a **watch tower** (likely a border or coastal surveillance post) at Rezovo. Its presence signifies the village's status as a guarded national border point, underscoring the security measures in place.
This photo provides a general view of the **Turkish side** of the border area, showing the landscape and any coastal features or development visible from Rezovo.

photos.title: Forbidden at Rezovo
photos.alt: The Turkish have forbidden to take photos of their border. Though you can take as many pictures as you want. The absurd is that there is no way for them to cross the border and do you a harm :)

sections.content: This photo captures the concept of the **forbidden** act of taking pictures of the Turkish border, highlighting a potential rule on the Turkish side. The accompanying commentary points out the absurdity that, despite the restriction, there is a geographical barrier (the River Rezovo) preventing physical confrontation.

photos.title: Ordinary House at Rezovo
photos.alt: You will see many ordinary (even poor) houses in Rezovo.

sections.content: This photo depicts an **ordinary (even poor) house** in Rezovo. This serves to illustrate the modest nature of the village's local architecture and infrastructure, contrasting with the often polished images of major resorts.

This photo shows a sign or feature related to the **Tsarevo Municipality**, under which Rezovo falls. This highlights the administrative and regional context of the village within the broader Bulgarian Black Sea coast area.

photos.title: Dalian at Rezovo
photos.alt: This sign explains that this is a private club and you should not bother the insiders :)

sections.content: This photo features a sign for '**Dalian**' that explains it is a **private club** and warns visitors **not to bother the insiders**. This gives a glimpse into the local social environment, suggesting the presence of exclusive establishments.

This photo shows a sign indicating that **bathing is forbidden** (or restricted) at this specific location in Rezovo. This is highly relevant information for visitors planning to swim, suggesting potential hazards or border restrictions in that area.
This photo captures the marker or sign defining the **Bulgarian Border** at Rezovo, emphasizing the official boundary demarcation at this coastal point.
This photo features **bells**, likely belonging to a local chapel or church in Rezovo, underscoring the village's Orthodox Christian heritage and the role of religious symbols in the local culture.

photos.title: Chapel at Rezovo
photos.alt: Rezovo does its best to promote the Christianity in opposite to the neighboring Islam.

sections.content: This photo showcases a **chapel** at Rezovo, accompanied by the comment that the village is actively trying to **promote Christianity in opposition to the neighboring Islam**. This highlights the religious and cultural significance of the chapel as a symbol near the border.

This photo captures a scene titled **Horse Romance**, likely depicting horses in a natural setting near the village. This suggests the presence of undeveloped, natural areas around Rezovo and the local wildlife or use of horses.
This photograph provides a general, scenic view of Rezovo (titled 'Rezovo25'), documenting the village's overall appearance, position relative to the coast, and landscape features.

This photo is titled '**Tours**' and likely depicts information or facilities related to organized excursions available in Rezovo, possibly including boat trips up the river or to nearby nature spots.

This photo titled '**End**' visually represents the terminus of the road or the boundary of the settled area in Rezovo, often associated with the border line itself, marking the geographical limit of the village.

gallery_description.heading: About Rezovo
gallery_description.content: Rezovo is a destination along Bulgaria's beautiful Black Sea coast. This destination features Sandy beach, Bulgarian coastal atmosphere, summer facilities, making it ideal for beach lovers, families, travelers seeking authentic Bulgarian coast. The Bulgarian Black Sea coast offers 378 kilometers of diverse beaches, and Rezovo provides its own unique character and attractions.

gallery_description.heading: What to Expect
gallery_description.content: The beach area at Rezovo features fine to medium sand typical of Black Sea beaches. During summer months (June-September), water temperatures range from 22-25°C (72-77°F), perfect for swimming. The area offers standard beach amenities including umbrella and sunbed rentals (typically 10-20 BGN per day), changing facilities, and food services. Peak season runs from mid-July through mid-August, when the beaches are busiest and prices highest.

gallery_description.heading: Getting There & Practical Information
gallery_description.content: The nearest airports are Burgas (BOJ) and Varna (VAR), both serving international and domestic flights. Bus services connect major coastal towns during summer. Accommodation ranges from budget guesthouses (40-60 BGN/night) to mid-range hotels (80-150 BGN/night). Bulgaria uses the Bulgarian Lev (BGN), approximately 2 BGN = 1 EUR. English is commonly spoken in tourist areas.

gallery_description.heading: Nearby Attractions
gallery_description.content: Beyond the beach, visitors can explore other Black Sea destinations, local attractions. The Bulgarian coast combines natural beauty with historical sites, traditional villages, and opportunities for hiking, water sports, and cultural experiences. Each location offers something unique while maintaining authentic Bulgarian coastal character.

gallery_description.heading: Best Time to Visit
gallery_description.content: June and September offer excellent weather with fewer crowds and better prices compared to peak July-August. Water is warm enough for comfortable swimming from mid-June through mid-September. For the quietest experience and best value, consider late May or early October, though some facilities may have reduced hours.

gallery_description.heading: Tips for Visitors
gallery_description.content: Bring high SPF sunscreen (30+) as the sun is strong. Many beach vendors prefer cash. Learning a few Bulgarian phrases is appreciated. Book accommodations in advance for July-August. Consider renting a car to explore multiple beaches. Try local restaurants for authentic Bulgarian cuisine and fresh Black Sea fish. Beach umbrellas and sunbeds are available but bringing your own gear saves money.
